content: No information provided. The Congress declares its policy to promote Indian self-determination and economic self-sufficiency. The Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community has managed irrigation works since 1997 and is capable of full operation. The irrigation works, consisting of canals, ditches, wells, reservoirs, and ponds on trust lands, have been used for over 100 years for water distribution. The Congress aims to promote Indian self-determination and economic self-sufficiency. The Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community has managed irrigation works since 1997, which have been used for over 100 years for water distribution. Ownership of the works is being transferred to the Community to enhance its economic development and water service capabilities. Ownership of the irrigation works is being transferred to the Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community by the United States to enhance economic development and water service capabilities. The United States is transferring ownership of irrigation works to the Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community to improve economic development and water service capabilities. The Secretary of the Interior will transfer ownership of irrigation works to the Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community in accordance with the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act allows the Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community to have full ownership and operating authority over irrigation works. The Community must operate the irrigation works in compliance with federal trust responsibilities and uniform laws and regulations for water management. The Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community has full ownership and operating authority over irrigation works, managing water resources to ensure fair distribution and conservation. This includes a process for distribution, allocation, pricing, and regulation of water to achieve maximum beneficial use and conservation in response to changing land and water uses. The Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community has full ownership and operating authority over irrigation works, managing water resources for fair distribution and conservation. A due process system is in place for considering and determining requests for water use on individual lands, with provisions for appeal and adjudication. Any modifications to laws and regulations must be shared with the Secretary at least 120 days prior to their effective date, ensuring allottees' rights are protected. Upon conveyance of the irrigation works, the United States will not be liable for damages, except for negligence prior to the Act's enactment. Charges for construction on the Community's reservation are canceled. Upon conveyance of the irrigation works, the United States will not be liable for damages, except for negligence prior to the Act's enactment. Charges for construction on the Community's reservation are canceled. The irrigation works will no longer be considered a Bureau of Indian Affairs project and will not be eligible for federal benefits solely based on its previous status. This does not limit the Community's eligibility for other federal benefits. SEC. 3. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER LAWS. This Act does not diminish the trust responsibility of the United States to the Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community or individual Indians within the reservation.
